Sunday, May 10, 2015.name: Asian Pacific American Heritage Month
Sunday, May 10, 2015.title: Asian Pacific American Heritage Month
Sunday, May 10, 2015.Date, Time and Location:
all day, May 10, 2015Entire Campus
                
                    Show all occurrences.
Sunday, May 10, 2015.Other Dates and Times: Every day, all day, May 1, 2015 - May 31, 2015Entire Campus
Sunday, May 10, 2015.Event Details: Culture/Religion: National CelebrationMay is Asian Pacific American Heritage Month - a celebration of Asians and Pacific Islanders in the United States. A rather broad term, Asian-Pacific encompasses all of the Asian continent and the Pacific Islands of Melanesia (New Guinea, New Caledonia, Vanuatu, Fiji and the Solomon Islands), Micronesia (Marianas, Guam, Wake Island, Palau, Marshall Islands, Kiribati, Nauru and the Federated States of Micronesia) and Polynesia (New Zealand, Hawiian Islands, Rotuma, Midway Islands, Samoa, American Samoa, Tonga, Tuvalu, Cook Islands, French Polynesia and Easter Island). Like most commemorative months, Asian-Pacific Heritage Month originated in a congressional bill. In June 1977, Reps. Frank Horton of New York and Norman Y. Mineta of California introduced a House resolution that called upon the president to proclaim the first ten days of May as Asian-Pacific Heritage Week. The following month, senators Daniel Inouye and Spark Matsunaga introduced a similar bill in the Senate. Both were passed. On October 5, 1978, President Jimmy Carter signed a Joint Resolution designating the annual celebration. Twelve years later, President George H.W. Bush signed an extension making the week-ling celebration into a month-ling celebration. In 1992, the official designation of May as Asian-Pacific American Heritage Month was signed into law.The month of May was chosen to commemorate the immigration of the first Japanese to the United States on May 7, 1843, and to mark the anniversary of the completion of the transcontinental railroad on May 10, 1869. The majority of the workers who laid the tracks were Chinese immigrants.
Sunday, May 10, 2015.Admission: Open to current students, faculty, staff.
Sunday, May 10, 2015.Contact: Diversity and Inclusion, Division Contact at diversityandinclusion@missouristate.edu or (417) 836 - 3736.

Monday, May 11, 2015.Event Details: The BFA Senior Exhibition is on view at Brick City Gallery, 215 West Mill Street, Springfield. This is a First Friday Art Walk event. Eighteen Senior students completing degree requirements of the Bachelor of Fine Arts/Studio Art are exhibiting their art at Brick City gallery, April 29-May 12. Included in this exhibition are: Emily Boone, Olivia Duvall, Meghan Walsh, Claire Franke, James Conner and Jonathan Bolli: Photography; Arwen Watkins and Katelyn Butler: Metals; Laci Carlisle: Sculpture; John Gueltzau and Twan Dickison: Ceramics; Charles “Andy” Corbett and Ali Parmenter: Painting; Aaron Ivic, Printmaking; Jacob Stewart, Megan Rhoden, Tyler Thrasher and Dylan Pieper: Animation Gallery hours are 11 a.m. – 6 p.m. M-F; Noon-5 p.m. Saturday; and by appointment
Monday, May 11, 2015.Admission: Open to current students, future students, family of students, alumni, faculty, staff, community, visitors.
Monday, May 11, 2015.Contact: Robin Lowe, Director, Brick City Gallery at RLowe@MissouriState.edu or (417) 836 - 6794.

Monday, May 11, 2015.name: Electronic Arts Student Showcase
Monday, May 11, 2015.title: Electronic Arts Student Showcase
Monday, May 11, 2015.Date, Time and Location: 6:30 PM - 10:00 PM, May 11, 2015Plaster Student Union, Robert W. Theatre
Monday, May 11, 2015.Event Details:
The Electronic Arts Student ShowcasePlease join us for the 16th annual EA Showcase on Monday, May 11. The showcase will take place in the Plaster Student Union Theatre from 7:00 to 9:30 p.m. Seating starts at 6:30 p.m.This year's screening will feature an original short film, What Makes Us Human; an experimental narrative, Dead on Time, based on the album, Dead Man's Bones; a documentary chronicling the formation of the DIY band, High Hoax; an interactive scavenger app for mobile devices called SEEK; and the futuristic video game, TAR.  This event is free and open to the public.  Parking available in Lot 24 (access off National Ave, one block south of Grand Street) or in the Park & Ride facility next to  Hammons Hall for the Performing Arts — take MSU Shuttle to the PSU theatre. 
                Electronic Arts Student ShowcasePlaster Student Union Theatre1110 E. Madison AveSpringfield , MO 65897 Monday, May 11, 2015 7:00 to 10 p.m.
Monday, May 11, 2015.Admission: Open to current students, future students, family of students, alumni, faculty, staff, community.
Monday, May 11, 2015.Contact: Mark Biggs, Interim Associate Dean at MarkBiggs@MissouriState.edu or (417) 836 - 5247.

Thursday, May 14, 2015.name: "Analyzing & Managing Your Cash Flow"
Thursday, May 14, 2015.title: "Analyzing & Managing Your Cash Flow"
Thursday, May 14, 2015.Date, Time and Location: 9:00 AM - 12:00 PM, May 14, 2015Plaster Center for Free Enterprise and Business Development, Robert W.
Thursday, May 14, 2015.Event Details:
In this second class of the financial management series, we'll take a close look at where cash comes from in a small business, where it's used in day-to-day operations and how to identify and correct cash flow problems. You'll be able to identify key information on cash flow statements and be able to follow the path of cash as it travels through your company. You'll identify cash flow strategies to use in your organization. You'll become familiar with the sources and uses of cash, ratios and the most common "gobblers" of cash in any business. This isn't theory - it's practical application for real businesses - like yours!
                Rayanna Anderson, SBTDC Director
Thursday, May 14, 2015.Event Sponsor: Small Business and Technology Development Center (SBTDC)
Thursday, May 14, 2015.Admission: Open to current students, future students, family of students, alumni, faculty, staff, community, visitors.
Thursday, May 14, 2015.Contact: Tara Horton, Training Coordinator Sbtdc at TaraHorton@MissouriState.edu or (417) 837 - 2617.

Thursday, May 14, 2015.name: Tax Compliance Workshop
Thursday, May 14, 2015.title: Tax Compliance Workshop
Thursday, May 14, 2015.Date, Time and Location: 9:00 AM - 4:00 PM, May 14, 2015Plaster Student Union, Robert W.
Thursday, May 14, 2015.Event Details: GO LEAD hosts the IRS Tax Compliance Workshop for Small and Medium-Size Tax-Exempt Organizations. This workshop explains what 501(c)(3) organizations must do to keep their tax-exempt status and comply with tax obligations. Topics include: introduction tax-exempt status, unrelated business income, employment issues, form 990 series, and required disclosures.Continuing education credits, are being offered, through professional programs. These credits will be worth 6 hours and include: CEU, CPE, and CLE. Two outstanding IRS employees, Cheryl A. Teser and James Harmon, have provided expansive knowledge and experience and may help you further your understanding of how to keep your 501(c)(3) organization up-to-date with tax obligations.
Thursday, May 14, 2015.Admission: Open to current students, family of students, alumni, faculty, staff, community.
Thursday, May 14, 2015.Contact: Cody Brewington, Non-Credit Outreach Program Coordinator at CodyBrewington@MissouriState.edu or (417) 836 - 8974.

Thursday, May 14, 2015.name: Asian Pacific American Heritage Month
Thursday, May 14, 2015.title: Asian Pacific American Heritage Month
Thursday, May 14, 2015.Date, Time and Location:
all day, May 14, 2015Entire Campus
                
                    Show all occurrences.
Thursday, May 14, 2015.Other Dates and Times: Every day, all day, May 1, 2015 - May 31, 2015Entire Campus
Thursday, May 14, 2015.Event Details: Culture/Religion: National CelebrationMay is Asian Pacific American Heritage Month - a celebration of Asians and Pacific Islanders in the United States. A rather broad term, Asian-Pacific encompasses all of the Asian continent and the Pacific Islands of Melanesia (New Guinea, New Caledonia, Vanuatu, Fiji and the Solomon Islands), Micronesia (Marianas, Guam, Wake Island, Palau, Marshall Islands, Kiribati, Nauru and the Federated States of Micronesia) and Polynesia (New Zealand, Hawiian Islands, Rotuma, Midway Islands, Samoa, American Samoa, Tonga, Tuvalu, Cook Islands, French Polynesia and Easter Island). Like most commemorative months, Asian-Pacific Heritage Month originated in a congressional bill. In June 1977, Reps. Frank Horton of New York and Norman Y. Mineta of California introduced a House resolution that called upon the president to proclaim the first ten days of May as Asian-Pacific Heritage Week. The following month, senators Daniel Inouye and Spark Matsunaga introduced a similar bill in the Senate. Both were passed. On October 5, 1978, President Jimmy Carter signed a Joint Resolution designating the annual celebration. Twelve years later, President George H.W. Bush signed an extension making the week-ling celebration into a month-ling celebration. In 1992, the official designation of May as Asian-Pacific American Heritage Month was signed into law.The month of May was chosen to commemorate the immigration of the first Japanese to the United States on May 7, 1843, and to mark the anniversary of the completion of the transcontinental railroad on May 10, 1869. The majority of the workers who laid the tracks were Chinese immigrants.
Thursday, May 14, 2015.Admission: Open to current students, faculty, staff.
Thursday, May 14, 2015.Contact: Diversity and Inclusion, Division Contact at diversityandinclusion@missouristate.edu or (417) 836 - 3736.
